head.title: Top-Down Syntheses of Nickel-Based Structured Catalysts for Hydrogen Production from Ammonia | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Top-Down Syntheses of Nickel-Based Structured Catalysts for Hydrogen Production from Ammonia

We report the fabrication and catalytic performance evaluation of highly active and stable nickel (Ni)-based structured catalysts for ammonia dehydrogenation with nearly complete conversion using nonprecious metal catalysts. Low-temperature chemical alloying (LTCA) followed by selective aluminum (Al) dealloying was utilized to synthesize foam-type structured catalysts ready for implementation in commercial-scale catalytic reactors. The crystalline phases of Ni–Al alloy (NiAl3, Ni2Al3, or both) in the near-surface layer were controlled by tuning the alloying time. The best-performing catalyst was obtained from a Ni foam substrate with a NiAl3/Ni2Al3 overlayer synthesized by LTCA at 400 °C for 20 h. The developed Ni catalyst exhibited an activity enhancement of 10-fold over the nontreated Ni foam and showed outstanding activities of 15 800 molH2molNi–1h–1 (TOF: 4.39 s–1) and 19 978 molH2molNi–1h–1 (TOF: 5.55 s–1) at 550 and 600 °C, respectively. This performance is unprecedented compared with previously reported Ni-based ammonia cracking catalysts with higher-end performance (TOFs of 0.08–1.45 s–1 at 550 °C). Moreover, this catalyst showed excellent stability for 100 h at 600 °C while discharging an extremely low NH3 concentration of 1034 ppm. The NH3 concentration in the exhaust gas was further reduced to 690 and 271 ppm at 700 and 800 °C, respectively, while no deactivation was observed at these elevated temperatures. Through material characterizations, we clarified that controlling the degree of Al alloying in the outermost layer of Ni is a crucial factor in determining the activity and stability because residual Al possibly modifies the electronic structure of Ni for enhanced activity as well as transforming to acidic alumina for increased intrinsic activity and stability.

div.p:
We report the fabrication and catalytic performance evaluation of highly active and stable nickel (Ni)-based structured catalysts for ammonia dehydrogenation with nearly complete conversion using nonprecious metal catalysts. Low-temperature chemical alloying (LTCA) followed by selective aluminum (Al) dealloying was utilized to synthesize foam-type structured catalysts ready for implementation in commercial-scale catalytic reactors. The crystalline phases of Ni–Al alloy (NiAl
3
, Ni
2
Al
3
, or both) in the near-surface layer were controlled by tuning the alloying time. The best-performing catalyst was obtained from a Ni foam substrate with a NiAl
3
/Ni
2
Al
3
overlayer synthesized by LTCA at 400 °C for 20 h. The developed Ni catalyst exhibited an activity enhancement of 10-fold over the nontreated Ni foam and showed outstanding activities of 15 800 mol
H2
mol
Ni
–1
h
–1
(TOF: 4.39 s
–1
) and 19 978 mol
H2
mol
Ni
–1
h
–1
(TOF: 5.55 s
–1
) at 550 and 600 °C, respectively. This performance is unprecedented compared with previously reported Ni-based ammonia cracking catalysts with higher-end performance (TOFs of 0.08–1.45 s
–1
at 550 °C). Moreover, this catalyst showed excellent stability for 100 h at 600 °C while discharging an extremely low NH
3
concentration of 1034 ppm. The NH
3
concentration in the exhaust gas was further reduced to 690 and 271 ppm at 700 and 800 °C, respectively, while no deactivation was observed at these elevated temperatures. Through material characterizations, we clarified that controlling the degree of Al alloying in the outermost layer of Ni is a crucial factor in determining the activity and stability because residual Al possibly modifies the electronic structure of Ni for enhanced activity as well as transforming to acidic alumina for increased intrinsic activity and stability.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Ammonia is a promising candidate as a hydrogen carrier,
(1)
mainly owing to its high hydrogen storage density (17.7 wt %, 10.8 kg H
2
/100 L or 108 g/L at 20 °C), low price (U.S. $494/ton as of March 2020), and net-zero emissions of CO
x
and NO
x
.
(2−4)
Given that mass production facilities and distribution infrastructures for ammonia are already well-established in countries with a growing interest in hydrogen, utilizing ammonia as a hydrogen carrier appears to be a competitive option for reducing the hydrogen price to a level as low as U.S. $3.6/kg
H2
.
(5)
The development of heterogeneous catalysts for ammonia decomposition (AD) is heavily focused on low-temperature AD catalysts working at <450 °C.
(6)
However, developing AD catalysts with superior thermal stability is also worthwhile for working at higher temperatures (>500 °C), where the thermodynamic level of residual NH
3
is below 2640 ppm. A decrease in residual NH
3
simplifies downstream purification steps, such as temperature swing adsorption (TSA) and pressure swing adsorption (PSA). Both methods are necessary to produce hydrogen that satisfies stringent purity standards (e.g., polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell, NH
3
< 1 ppm
(7)
). However, these adsorptive processes for removing strong adsorbates such as CO
2
, NH
3
, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are energy-intensive because they require hot steam or vacuum conditions for adsorbent regeneration.
(8,9)
Therefore, in the pursuit of enhanced overall system efficiency considering both ammonia dehydrogenation and the above-mentioned downstream purification steps, it is necessary to reduce the NH
3
concentration in the feed for the purification by intentionally operating NH
3
dehydrogenation systems at >500 °C.

Another advantage of AD at >500 °C is its potential to adopt nonprecious metals such as Ni. Although Ru has the highest AD catalytic activity due to its near-optimal nitrogen binding energy,
(10,11)
its use makes catalyst manufacturing expensive, potentially deterring the commercialization of NH
3
-based hydrogen production systems. One plausible strategy for more cost-effective hydrogen production from ammonia is to replace Ru with less expensive metals.
(12−14)
Ganley et al. suggested that the AD activity varies in the order Ru > Ni > Rh > Co > Ir;
(15)
thus, Ni can be an attractive alternative considering its lower price compared to that of Ru ($15.7/kg
Ni
vs $8680/kg
Ru
as of November 2020
(16,17)
) and its adequate reactivity toward AD. The lower intrinsic activity of Ni has been overcome by operating at higher temperatures (600–700 °C) compared to that of Ru-based catalysts (450–550 °C) in similar space velocities to achieve nearly complete NH
3
conversion.
(18)
However, higher operational temperatures (>500 °C) often accelerate the thermal degradation of nickel (Ni)-based catalysts by the sintering of Ni active sites, which may relate to the lower durability of the Ni nanoparticle-based catalysts reported in the literature.
(19−21)

On the other hand, Ni catalysts for AD applications have mainly focused on controlling the electronic structure of Ni, metal–support interaction, and surficial acidity (or basicity) to achieve the optimal absorbate binding energies and enhance durability while maintaining high activity. Recently, Sima et al. reported Ni-based catalysts with enhanced AD activities at lower temperatures (450–550 °C) by adopting an advanced CeO
2
–ZrO
2
support with Al doping.
(22)
Wu et al. demonstrated K-doped bimetallic NiCo-loaded SiO
2
catalyst with improved AD stability.
(23)
Zhang and Feng research group added MgO to Ni/La
2
O
3
catalyst for higher surface oxygen concentration and basicity of the support, leading to better AD performance.
(24)
Zhao et al. reported an enhanced AD activity by utilizing the Ni-induced structural transformation of hydrocalumite-layered double hydroxides (LDH) into hydrombobomkulite.
(25)

Although heterogeneous catalysts have been widely deployed until now, the types of catalysts (powder vs pellet vs structured catalyst) are worth considering to realize economic large-scale hydrogen production from ammonia. Structured catalysts have a lower geometric surface area than that of powder and pellet catalysts; however, in the case of strong endothermic gas-phase chemical reactions such as AD (reaction heat of 53.2 kJ/mol
NH3
, reacted at 500 °C), the adoption of the structured catalysts has several benefits for the overall system efficiency.
(26,27)
This is due to their ability to facilitate heat transfer, reduce pressure drop, and alleviate channeling effects.
(28−30)
In particular, a open-celled metal foam as the structured catalyst can improve the flow distribution and heat and mass transfers.

Particularly, Ni foam has been interested as a lightweight and thermally conductive catalytic scaffold that can be mechanically stable
(31)
and catalytically functional via surface engineering. So far, researchers have mainly focused on the wash-coating or electrodeposition of oxide-supported metals or alloy nanoparticles onto the Ni substrates to achieve satisfactory performance. With respect to Ni foam electrode development, the Li research group fabricated the hydrothermally prepared Fe-doped β-Ni(OH)
2
on Ni foam with a lower overpotential for oxygen evolution reaction.
(32)
Hu et al. synthesized N-doped NiZnCu-LDH with the reduced graphene oxide on the Ni foam for various water electrolysis.
(33)
Besides, Wang et al. developed a highly performing Ru–Ni-loaded Ni foam catalyst by utilizing the combined method of electroless plating and electroplating for NaBH
4
methanolysis.
(34)

Still, the stability of the supported metal foam catalysts can come into question due to the sintering of the deposited nanoparticle catalysts, especially at higher operational temperatures. In an attempt to solve the challenges mentioned above, we carried out catalytic activation on a 3D-structured Ni foam via surface modification composed of gas-phase surface alloying, called low-temperature chemical alloying (LTCA), with aluminum (Al) as a sacrificial element.
(35−37)
Then, this was followed by selective Al dealloying in the liquid phase. LTCA is distinctive from conventional Al alloying processes requiring a high temperature of >600 °C. LTCA is an energy-efficient process because of its lower alloying temperature of <500 °C,
(36−41)
but it is still capable of conducting surface alloying on various types of Ni substrates ranging from powder to 3D-structured substrates (e.g., mesh, foam, plate, etc.). The surface alloying leads to the formation of various Ni–Al alloy coating layers on the Ni surface with a submicron thickness, as demonstrated previously.
(37)
In addition, this method is useful for fabricating a porous Ni surface having aluminum oxide layers that can play a significant role as a support matrix to hinder the sintering of nanostructured Ni catalysts while retaining the metallic state of the core material with high thermal conductivity (ca. 70 W/(m K) at 500–700 °C
(42)
).

In the present study, the Ni–Al alloy compositions in the outer layers were controlled by adjusting the aluminizing time at 400 °C through LTCA. The subsequent Al leaching on the samples, as an Al dealloying process, formed high-surface-area Ni-structured catalysts with different morphologies. The different Ni-structured catalysts were first evaluated for AD. Then, we clarified how the types of Ni–Al layers as starting materials with different dealloying trends affected both the surface area and the catalytic activity. The catalytic stability of the best-performing catalyst was also clarified. We further explored the material and chemical characteristics such as alloy composition, microstructure, nanostructure, metal dispersion, chemical state, reduction behavior, acidity, and surface enhancement factor (SEF) of the as-developed samples using XRD, FESEM-EDS, TEM, H
2
pulse chemisorption, XPS, H
2
-TPR, NH
3
-TPD, and a surface area measurement setup.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 2.1. Preparation of Ni Foam with Ni–Al Alloy Outer Layers
div.div:
Ni foam (manufacturer, Alantum; nominal cell size, 1200 μm; strut thickness, 16 μm; thickness, 3.0 mm) was selected as the substrate and cut into a size of 10 × 100 × 1.9 mm
3
(length × width × height). The Ni foam was sonicated in ethanol for 5 min, dipped in 10% HCI solution for 30 s, and dried at ambient temperature after rinsing with deionized water. Ni foam of 3.0 g was mixed with Al powder (manufacturer, Ecka; particle size, 23 μm) of 3.0 g and an AlCl
3
activator (manufacturer, Junsei) of 0.18 g. A quartz reactor (Pyrex container) enclosing all reagents was sealed after evacuation to 10 Pa and then heated using an electric furnace at 400 °C for 5–20 h at a 1.5 °C·min
–1
and a reactor rotation speed of 20 rpm. After the heat treatment process, the quartz reactor was allowed to cool to ambient temperature with the furnace. The samples are denoted in the text by the abbreviation “
x
h
”, where
x
indicates the time employed.

To transform the Ni
–
Al alloy layer into high-surface-area porous Ni, we implemented selective Al leaching in a base solution: the alkaline solution containing 30 wt % of potassium hydroxide (KOH, Sigma-Aldrich, ≥85%) and 10 wt % of potassium sodium tartrate tetrahydrate (KNaC
4
H
4
O
6
·4H
2
O, Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) with the balance of distilled water was used as a leaching agent, and the leaching was conducted at 80 °C for 1 h. The Al leaching process is described in
eqs 1
–
3
. The treated Ni foam was rinsed several times with deionized water. After this process, the color of the sample turned black. This color change means that the surface of the Ni foam became porous. Before materials characterization or NH
3
decomposition test, the sample was dried at ambient temperature after blowing with N
2
gas. The Al leached samples are denoted in the text by adding the letter L after the abbreviation “
x
h
” (e.g., 20 h-L).
(1)
(2)
(3)

Morphological and compositional analyses of both the outer surface and the cross-section of the Ni foams and compositional profiles were conducted using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; InspectF, FEI Co.) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS; Apollo X, Edax Inc.). The backscattered electron (BSE) mode was applied to the cross-sectional SEM for clear phase distinction. In the BSE mode, the contrast of the SEM image can be intensified by the average atomic number of the region of interest. The crystalline phases of the Ni
–
Al alloy layer on the Ni foams were studied using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD; model, Dmax2500; scanning mode, continuous; 2θ range, 20°–80°; scanning rate, 0.05°/s; radiation, Cu Kα [λ = 0.154 nm]). The crystallinity and morphology in the nanoscale of the as-developed Ni
–
Al alloy covered Ni foams before and after Al leaching were analyzed via high-resolution scanning/transmission electron microscopy (HR-STEM; Talos F200X, Thermo Scientific) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Specimens for TEM analysis were prepared using a focused ion beam (FIB; Helios NanoLab 600, FEI).

The surface elemental compositions and chemical states were analyzed via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; K-Alpha+, Thermo Scientific) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV, 12 kV, 1.16 mA, and 400 μm spot size). The surface area of the treated Ni foams (geometric surface area, 1.2 × 0.9 cm
2
) was measured with a double-layer capacitance (DLC) method using a potentiostat (VersaSTAT 3, Princeton Applied Research). The DLC method is useful for evaluating the surface area of conducting materials, such as Ni, by measuring the charging/discharging currents as a function of the scan rates in a nonfaradaic voltage range.
(43)
Cyclic voltammetry for this method was conducted from −0.255 to −0.155 V (vs Ag/AgCl reference electrode) at scan rates of 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3 V·s
–1
in a N
2
-saturated 0.5 M KOH solution. H
2
pulse chemisorption to measure the metal dispersion of the developed catalyst was conducted using an AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. The sample was first pretreated with 10% H
2
/Ar gas at a temperature of 600 °C for 1 h and then the reactor temperature was cooled down to 35 °C for the chemisorption. From the measured metal dispersions, the amount of catalytically active Ni (mol) was calculated by multiplying the total weight of the catalyst (
g
cat
) and the metal dispersion and dividing it by the atomic weight of nickel (58.7 g/mol).

H
2
temperature-programmed reduction (H
2
-TPR) and NH
3
temperature-programmed desorption (NH
3
-TPD) were carried out to check the acidity of the developed Ni catalysts using a BELCAT-M catalyst analyzer (BEL Japan, Inc.) with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to the H
2
-TPR measurement, the sample (140 mg) was loaded in a quartz tube and pretreated with 99.999% Ar at 300 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 40 °C, the sample cell was again heated to 900 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C min
–1
under a continuous flow of 10% H
2
/Ar with a flow rate of 50 mL min
–1
. For the NH
3
-TPD test, 140 mg of the sample was prereduced in pure H
2
at 600 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 100 °C, NH
3
absorption was conducted by feeding 10% NH
3
/He gas at a flow rate of 50 mL min
–1
for 30 min, and then sweeping with He for 1 h to remove physisorbed or weakly bound species while stabilizing the TCD baseline. NH
3
desorption was carried out from 100 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min
–1
and a He flow rate of 30 mL min
–1
.

A detailed description of an AD test setup has been reported elsewhere.
(36)
Catalytic activity toward AD of the as-developed Ni catalysts was evaluated in a vertical quartz tube reactor (12.7 mm in diameter, 500 mm in length), where the sample (400 mg) was loaded in the middle of the reactor. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of ammonia and the catalyst bed temperatures used for the AD test were varied at 600–2000 mLg
cat
–1
h
–1
and 400–600 °C, respectively. Prior to the AD reaction, the catalysts were reduced with 100 mL min
–1
of pure H
2
gas at 600 °C for 1 h. The gas compositions of NH
3
, N
2
, and H
2
were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC; 7890A, Agilent Technologies, Inc.) system equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD) and two columns (J&W HP-PLOT molecular sieve GC Column, 19091P-MS4; J&W PoraPLOT Amines GC Column, CP7591). Due to the detection limit of GC on ammonia concentration down to 0.1 mol %, the catalyst stability test was performed by measuring the residual NH
3
concentration less than 0.1 mol % in the outlet gas using an IR-based gas analyzer with a resolution of 1 ppm (Airwell Plus 7, Kinsco Technology Co., Ltd., Korea) under high-temperature conditions of 600–800 °C. Ammonia conversion by AD was calculated using
eq 4
, where
V̇
̇
NH3, inlet
, and
V̇
̇
NH3, reacted
represent the molar flow rates of NH
3
in the inlet stream and decomposed to N
2
, and H
2
during AD, respectively. Thermodynamic equilibrium of AD (
eq 5
) at various temperatures in atmospheric pressure were estimated using HSC Chemistry 10 by the Gibbs free energy minimization.
(4)
(5)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a shows how LTCA with different alloying durations (5, 10, and 20 h) at 400 °C induces the formation and transformation of the Ni–Al alloy overlayer on the Ni substrate. Experimental evidence was derived from XRD on the outer surface and FE-SEM/EDS on the cross section of the samples, as displayed in
Figure
1
b and c, respectively. In the cross-sectional FE-SEM images in BSE mode, Ni, NiAl
3
, and Ni
2
Al
3
are distinguishable by contrast. In addition, the EDS line scanning over the orange lines highlighted in the SEM images supplied further information for identifying different Ni–Al alloy phases by providing the atomic percent profiles of Ni and Al. The identification of the alloy phases was reconfirmed by XRD (
Figure
1
c). Note that peaks corresponding to the Ni substrate and the residual Al powder were detected more prominently than those for the Ni–Al alloys because of the scarcity of Ni–Al alloys relative to the Ni substrate and the Al powder. Therefore, the logarithmic scale was applied to the
y
-axis to closely scrutinize the XRD peaks corresponding to Ni–Al alloys with low intensity. In the case of the sample aluminized at 400 °C for 5 h, the main component of the outer layer was NiAl
3
. However, as the aluminizing time increased, Ni
2
Al
3
was formed between the NiAl
3
layer and the Ni substrate (10 h), and finally, most of the surface layer on the sample treated for 20 h was confirmed to be Ni
2
Al
3
with a very thin NiAl
3
layer near the top surface. The Ni–Al alloy overlayers of the samples treated for different durations were coated to a similar thickness (∼1 μm), and these overlayers uniformly existed on the entire surface of the Ni foam. To sum up the formation process of the Ni–Al alloy overlayer, the NiAl
3
layer was first formed on the Ni surface at the initial stage of LTCA under the continuous Al influx from the reaction between AlCl
x
(
x
=1,2)
and Ni. It is considered that the Al deposition rate predominated over the Al diffusion rate on the surface, which possibly led to Al-rich Ni–Al alloy, NiAl
3
. Next, the Ni
2
Al
3
layer was formed at the interface between the NiAl
3
layer and the underlying Ni substrate through the interdiffusion of Ni and Al under a thermal environment so-called Kirkendall effect.
(44)
The formation of the intermediate layer (Ni
2
Al
3
) can also be accounted for by its lower formation energy than that of NiAl
3
(NiAl
3
, −0.405 eV; Ni
2
Al
3
, −0.613
(45)
). Note that any defects such as the Kirkendall voids were hardly observed at the interfaces of each layer as shown in the cross-section SEM images (
Figure
1
b), presumably owing to relatively lower the LTCA temperature of 400 °C, compared to another Ni–Al foam synthesized at 1024 °C accompanied by the Kirkendall voids.
(46)

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) LTCA fabrication process composed of Ni aluminizing at 400 °C for 5–20 h to form Ni–Al alloy layers on the Ni substrate. (b) Cross-sectional SEM images of the aluminized samples with EDS line-scanning profiles of each sample (blue, Ni; orange, Al). (c) XRD patterns of each aluminized sample, plotted on a logarithmic scale for clarity. JCPDS patterns of NiAl
3
and Ni
2
Al
3
are included as reference spectra.

div.div:
Figure
2
a shows cross-sectional and top-surface FE-SEM images where Al leaching was performed on the outer Ni–Al alloy layers. These Al-leached samples showed columnar, porous, and rugged shapes, in contrast to the nonleached samples (
Figure
1
b). In detail, finer cracks were observed on the surface due to the in-plane shrinkage of the NiAl
3
alloy layer by Al leaching.
(47)
The microstructural evolution induced by removing the embedded Al atoms may increase the surface area of the Ni foam to a larger extent, which may be related to the number of total available surface sites for AD. Prior to the catalytic evaluation, the surface enhancement factor (SEF) and metal dispersion of different samples were measured, as summarized in
Figure
2
b. The SEFs (left
y
-axis in
Figure
2
b) are ranked as follows: 69.8 (5 h-L) > 63.6 (10 h-L) > 58.2 (20 h-L). As stated earlier, the prolonged alloying (>5 h) gradually transformed the Ni–Al alloy phase from NiAl
3
to Ni
2
Al
3
. Ni
2
Al
3
is more energetically stable and resistant to Al leaching,
(36)
which clarifies the observation that the SEF decreases with the aluminizing time. Despite its lower leaching kinetics, the presence of Ni
2
Al
3
in the catalytic layer could be helpful to improve the stability of the porous catalyst during vigorous gas bubbling in liquid or gas phase reactions at high temperatures.
(36,37)
The possible improved stability of the catalytic layer of samples with the increased aluminizing time (>10 h) may explain the trend of the metal dispersion vs the alloying time. The metal dispersions (right
y
-axis in
Figure
2
b) are ranked as follows: 0.08 (20 h-L) ≅ 0.08 (10 h-L) > 0.04 (5 h-L). This discrepancy in trends for the SEFs and metal dispersions (i.e., the number of actual active sites mainly composed of nickel) as a function of aluminizing time can be explained by the high-temperature (600 °C) pretreatment process during the H
2
pulse chemisorption, presumably inducing a significant Ni agglomeration and a reduction in the Ni surface area, especially for 5h-L sample. Note that the whole process of the SEF measurement was conducted at ambient temperature immediately after Al leaching, as stated in
Section 2.3
.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Cross-sectional and top-surface FE-SEM images of each sample after Al leaching for 1 h. (b) The SEFs (bar graph) and metal dispersion (red circle) of the Al-leached samples with different aluminizing durations (the as-received Ni foam is indicated as 0 h). The full cyclic voltammetry graphs are depicted in
Figure S1
.

div.h3: 3.3. AD Test and Insights on Reaction Kinetics and Thermodynamics
div.div:
The AD activity of the resulting catalysts was measured at different temperatures and GHSVs.
Figure
3
a shows the ammonia conversion as a function of the reaction temperature of the as-developed porous Ni catalysts (5 h-L, 10 h-L, and 20 h-L) as well as the as-received Ni foam, where the GHSV was 1000 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
. In the overall reaction temperature range, the AD activities of the as-fabricated catalysts are ranked as follows: 20 h-L > 10 h-L ∼ 5 h-L ≫ as-received Ni foam. The effectiveness of the surface modification was maximized at 500–550 °C, while the activity difference between the nontreated and treated samples decreased at either <500 °C or >550 °C.
Figure S3
of the
Supporting Information
(
SI
) represented the calculated apparent activation energies of each sample
(48)
based on the data reported in
Figure
3
a. The as-received Ni foam exhibited 91.5 kJ/mol, which well matches the known value.
(49)
The 5 h-L and 10 h-L samples showed 82.9 and 84.9 kJ/mol, respectively, which attained similar values while the slight difference may arise from different ammonia conversions at lower temperature (400–550 °C). The 20 h-L catalyst represented 60.0 kJ/mol, mainly due to the intrinsic higher activity in lower temperature. We expect this improvement might have come from the higher number of acidic sites of Al
2
O
3
made by the aluminizing and leaching, which could facilitate the adsorption of NH
3
on Ni.
(50)
The catalytic mass activities (i.e., activities normalized by catalyst weight) at 550 °C are reported in
Figure
3
b. The best-performing catalyst (20 h-L) shows a specific activity of 1.14 h
–1
and a mass activity of 0.943 mmol
H2
g
–1
cat
min
–1
, which is a mass activity enhancement of 10-fold over the nontreated Ni foam with a mass activity of 0.093 mmol
H2
g
–1
cat
min
–1
. The AD performance of the 20 h-L was further studied at various GHSVs and temperatures, as shown in
Figure
3
c. At 600 °C, the 20 h-L catalyst exhibited ∼99.9% NH
3
conversion under GHSV of 600–2000 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
and the possibility of obtaining higher NH
3
conversion at lower temperatures in the range of 400–550 °C under a GHSV lower than 600 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
. The GHSV, however, could not be lower than 600 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
owing to the limitations of the experimental setup. After confirming by the GC analysis that the 20 h-L catalyst was able to realize an ammonia conversion rate of ∼99.9% under a GHSV of 600 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
and a temperature of 600 °C, we proceeded with the long-term stability test using the NH
3
gas analyzer with higher resolution. The continuous test at 600 °C was conducted for 100 h; this catalyst showed ∼99.9% ammonia conversion throughout the test without any signs of deactivation. At the end of the durability test, the unreacted ammonia in the product gas as detected by the NH
3
gas analyzer was 1034 ppm, which is close to the thermodynamically calculated level of 1020 ppm (
Figure
3
d). We then evaluated concentrations of the residual NH
3
after the AD reactions at higher temperatures; the measured NH
3
concentrations at 700 and 800 °C were 690 and 271 ppm, respectively. These values are close to the theoretical values of 471 and 250 ppm, showing excellent activity at higher operational temperatures. The detailed information regarding the thermodynamic ammonia conversion at different temperatures is presented in
Figure S4
. Furthermore, we proceeded with continuous testing at 800 °C using this catalyst, and no degradation was observed during the operation (
Figure S5
).

div.p:
Figure 3. AD activity and stability of the as-developed porous Ni catalysts obtained from the Ni foam with different LTCA durations (5–20 h). (a) Effect of dehydrogenation temperature (400–600 °C) on ammonia conversion and (b) summary of the mass activity of different catalysts at 550 °C where GHSV was 1000 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
. (c) Effect of GHSV (600–2000 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
) on ammonia conversion at different temperatures (400–600 °C) of the best-performing catalyst, 20 h-L. (d) Long-term testing results of the 20 h-L catalyst for 100 h where the temperature and GHSV were 600 °C and 600 mL g
cat
–1
h
–1
, respectively. The inserted table shows the average residual ammonia concentrations in the exhaust gases measured at 600, 700, and 800 °C. Measurement of ammonia concentration at different temperatures was performed after the durability test at 600 °C for 100 h.

div.div:
Several microspectroscopic analyses were carried out to probe the underlying reasons why the 20 h-L catalyst outperformed the other catalysts and possessed excellent stability at elevated temperatures. We first investigated nanoscale morphological changes in the 5 and 20 h samples before and after Al leaching (5 h, 5 h-L, 20 h, and 20 h-L) using STEM and TEM. STEM and TEM images at different magnifications, EDS elemental mapping images of Ni, Al, and O elements, and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns are shown in
Figure
4
. In line with the XRD and FE-SEM results (
Figure
1
b,c), we reaffirmed that the formed Ni–Al alloy outer layers of both the 5 and 20 h samples were composed of two crystalline phases (NiAl
3
and Ni
2
Al
3
) with different relative thickness ratios (
Figure
4
a,c). The SAED pattern on the columnar grain of the 5 h sample confirms the presence of NiAl
3
. On the basis of the above-mentioned material characterizations, we came to a definite conclusion that the 5 h sample possessed the layer structure as presented in
Figure
1
a, which is the double-layer structure of the NiAl
3
layer stacked on the Ni
2
Al
3
layer. In the TEM image, the grain structure of the NiAl
3
-dominant region was found to be columnar and perpendicular to the Ni substrate while the Ni
2
Al
3
layer consisted of equiaxed grains with a size of 100 nm or less. This discrepancy in the crystal structure is presumably due to the different formation mechanisms of each layer. NiAl
3
was preferentially formed by a chemical reaction between the gas-phase AlCl
3
and Ni atoms at the surface of the Ni foam. However, Ni
2
Al
3
was formed by the interdiffusion of Ni and Al between the NiAl
3
layer and the Ni substrate in the presence of a continuous influx of heat energy required for atomic mixing. Furthermore, we observed that the 20 h sample treated with a longer aluminizing time had a thicker Ni
2
Al
3
layer, consistent with the above-explained formation mechanism.

div.p: Figure 4. STEM images with EDS elemental mapping for Ni, Al, and O and TEM images as well as SAED patterns for specific parts: (a) 5 h (i.e., sample with 5 h aluminization before Al leaching), (b) 5 h-L (i.e., sample with 5 h aluminization after Al leaching), (c) 20 h (i.e., sample with 20 h aluminization before Al leaching), and (d) 20 h-L (i.e., sample with 20 h aluminization after Al leaching).

div.div:
Figure
4
b,d presents the STEM and TEM results of the 5 h-L and 20 h-L samples, respectively. Through the EDS mapping, we confirmed that the samples after the leaching (i.e., 5 h-L and 20 h-L) showed significantly higher Ni and O concentrations and a lower Al concentration compared to the samples before the leaching (i.e., 5 and 20 h). This finding implies that Al was mostly leached out from the alloy layers and was partially transformed into an Al
2
O
3
matrix. Interestingly, there is a clear difference between the surface layer and the intermediate layer in terms of the degree of Al leaching, and the amount of Al
2
O
3
depended on the type of starting alloy layer. In particular, this trend is noticeable in the 20 h-L sample. Microstructures of the sample before and after the leaching showed some similarity in the grain shape. On the top surface layer originating from the NiAl
3
layer, we observed a columnar nanostructure with deep cracks perpendicular to the substrate. The intermediate layer obtained from Ni
2
Al
3
appeared to be a porous structure where fine Ni nanoparticles were mixed with alumina having a similar grain size. A similar conclusion can also be deduced from the STEM analyses. On the basis of HR-TEM, we can argue that the intermediate layer contained round Ni particles smaller than 10 nm surrounded by the Al
2
O
3
matrix. Needle-shaped Ni particles with a width of less than 10 nm were observed in the surface layer. This nanoparticle formation can also be confirmed by the corresponding SAED pattern, where the ring patterns were observed, indicating the random orientation of Ni nanograin. Most of the ring patterns matched with Ni (111), Ni (200), Ni (220), and Ni (311), and one coincided with NiO (111). To summarize, the porous surface of the 20 h-L sample was mostly composed of a needle-shaped Ni nanostructure smaller than 10 nm, and the intermediate layer contained an Al
2
O
3
matrix surrounding the spherical Ni nanoparticles. The microstructure of the 5 h-L sample is different from that of the 20 h-L sample where Ni nanostructures still existed. However, there were unclear boundaries in the internal region, which might explain the inconsistency between the trend of SEF vs aluminizing time and the trend of metal dispersion vs aluminizing time as referred to earlier. Our LTCA-based catalyst, particularly 20 h-L, derived from the NiAl
3
/Ni
2
Al
3
layer with Al leaching, resulted in a well-aligned Al
2
O
3
matrix that encapsulated Ni nanoparticles. We concluded that this unique internal structure for the Ni embedment is an underlying reason for the excellent thermal stability at high temperatures, as in previous literature.
(25,51)

Following the morphological analyses, the near-surface properties directly related to the catalytic activity for all the developed catalysts were analyzed using XPS, H
2
-TPR, and NH
3
-TPD. First,
Figure
5
and
Table
1
present the XPS results to identify the oxidation states of Ni and Al on the top surface of the catalysts. We analyzed the XPS spectra in the range of 64–76 eV, where the Ni 3p and Al 2p peaks can be simultaneously observed. After peak deconvolution using several bases of Ni and Al states with different oxidation states (Al
+3/2
, Al
0
, Ni
2+
, and Ni
0
), we found that the 20 h-L sample had the largest portion of metallic Ni and Al. This means that more Ni and Al atoms presumably maintained direct bonding with each other in the form of a Ni-rich Ni–Al alloy even after Al leaching as Ni
2
Al
3
tended to have a higher residual content of Al after leaching compared to that of the NiAl
3
alloy layers.
(52)

div.p:
Figure 5. Ni 3p and Al 2p XPS spectra of all leached samples (5 h-L, 10 h-L, and 20 h-L). Details regarding peak binding energies and area ratios are provided in
Table
1
.

div.div: Table 1. XPS Peak Binding Energy Values and Area Ratio of Metallic Peak over Total Peak Corresponding to Each Metal (Ni and Al)

H
2
-TPR analyses were conducted to investigate the reduction behavior of the as-developed catalysts (
Figure
6
a). The reduction peak positions and areas of the 5 h-L, 10 h-L, and 20 h-L samples are quite distinct from each other. The total area of the reduction peak indicates the amount of −OH and −O species on the catalyst surface, and the integrated values are ranked as follows: 5 h-L > 10 h-L > 20 h-L. The reduction peaks of all the samples were observed below 400 °C, indicating weak interaction between NiO and Al
2
O
3
. The strong NiO–Al
2
O
3
interaction corresponding to peaks observed above 400 °C may stem from the deep incorporation of NiO in the Al
2
O
3
lattice, hindering the removal of oxygen atoms attached to Ni active sites under the reductive atmosphere.
(53)
Ni alloyed with Al reportedly tends to have high resistance toward oxidation and the TPR result of the 20 h-L sample showed the smallest peak area and lowest peak positions. This observation corresponds to the XPS result indicating the presence of the direct Ni–Al bond in the 20 h-L sample; this finding is meaningful since alloying of metal active sites with heteroatoms significantly tune their electronic structure. Thus, the catalytic activity could be tailored by a subtle shift in the
d
-band center relative to the Fermi level according to a literature.
(54)
Figure
6
b shows the NH
3
desorption profiles of the as-developed catalysts. It was observed that the total NH
3
desorption peaks increased as the aluminizing time was increased, which indicates that the number of acidic sites of Al
2
O
3
was proportional to the aluminizing time. In addition, the position of each peak shifted to the right as the aluminizing time increased in the order of 20 h-L > 10 h-L > 5 h-L, meaning that the acidity of Al
2
O
3
also increased. The observable desorption peaks consisted of a low-temperature peak (150–300 °C) corresponding to the weak acid site, and the high-temperature peak (300–600 °C) corresponding to the strong acid site. According to other reports,
(55,56)
weak acid sites refer to the Al–O–H groups (Brønsted acid sites) on the catalytic surface, and the strong acid sites correspond to the surface Al sites (Lewis acid sites). These acidic sites could play a role in attracting ammonia molecules with lone pairs by electrostatic attraction as well as in decreasing the electron density of surface Ni atoms, which can also help increase the catalytic activity by boosting the spillover of adsorbed reactant species onto the active sites, and strengthen the nitrogen binding energy on the nickel’s active sites, respectively.
(57,58)
Therefore, from NH
3
-TPD results, we concluded that longer aluminizing time, eventually leading to higher content and acidity of Al
2
O
3
, would render the thermal stability to the porous catalytic layer.

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) H
2
-TPR and (b) NH
3
-TPD profiles of the as-developed samples (5 h-L, 10 h-L, and 20 h-L).

div.div:
To evaluate the catalytic activity and stability of the developed catalyst (20 h-L) compared with other Ni-based catalysts reported in the literature,
(18,59,60)
both the testing conditions and the results of different catalysts with similar AD reaction conditions are listed in
Table
2
. Due to the intrinsic nature of the as-developed Ni-structured catalysts, which have exposed active sites only on the surface, the hydrogen generation rates are expressed in two ways with different units (mmol
H2
g
cat
–1
min
–1
and mol
H2
mol
Ni
–1
h
–1
) for a fair comparison. On the basis of the results normalized to the number of exposed Ni active sites, the hydrogen generation rate of the as-developed catalyst is 15 800 mol
H2
mol
Ni
–1
h
–1
(TOF: 4.39 s
–1
) at 550 °C, which is at the higher end compared to other reports. In addition, it was observed that the catalyst has excellent durability without any degradation under harsh conditions with a high temperature of 800 °C (
Figure S3
), while other Ni catalysts reported elsewhere showed noticeable deactivation during the AD reaction at temperatures of 650–800 °C. Hence, we can conclude that the combination of LTCA and the post selective Al leaching process is a useful method for transforming a pristine open-cell Ni foam to catalytically active structured catalysts with a high surface area stabilized by the Al
2
O
3
matrix. This unique morphology made it possible for the developed catalysts to achieve both high activity and long-term stability. We expect our findings will have a significant impact on the landscape of hydrogen production from ammonia and accelerate the deployment of the hydrogen economy.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Structured Ni catalysts for ammonia decomposition (AD) were synthesized through surface enlargement on Ni foam by the following two steps: (i) Ni aluminizing by low-temperature chemical alloying (LTCA) and (ii) selective Al leaching. LTCA at 400 °C for different durations (5–20 h) formed Ni–Al alloy outer layers with submicron thickness. We observed the transition of dominant Ni–Al alloy phases from NiAl
3
(5 h) to Ni
2
Al
3
(20 h) in the outer layer for the alloying time, and significant surface enlargement of the Ni foam with the subsequent Al leaching process. Nanostructured Ni encapsulated in the Al
2
O
3
matrix was evolved on the outer-layer of the Ni substrate while preserving the Ni core structure, which can help enhance the system efficiency in terms of thermal heat transfer. The structured Ni catalysts with an enlarged surface area were tested for AD. We found that the longer the aluminizing time, the greater the increase in catalytic activity. This tendency is related to the Ni
2
Al
3
alloy layer, which can yield nanostructured Ni catalysts with Al as a dilute alloy element and Al
2
O
3
matrix with more acidic sites and stronger acidity. Besides, Al
2
O
3
could play a pivotal role in rendering thermal stability to the Ni nanostructure. We believe this is why the as-developed catalyst showed excellent durability at temperatures up to 800 °C. In conclusion, a foam-type Ni-structured catalyst was successfully synthesized through Al alloying/dealloying processing, and the hydrogen generation rate of this catalyst was as high as 15 800 mol
H2
mol
Ni
–1
h
–1
at 550 °C. This performance is considered to be at the higher end of the Ni-based catalysts reported so far in terms of both catalytic activity and durability.

A review. The possible role of ammonia in a future energy infrastructure is discussed. The review is focused on the catalytic decompn. of ammonia as a key step. Other aspects, such as the catalytic removal of ammonia from gasification product gas or direct ammonia fuel cells, are highlighted as well. The more general question of the integration of ammonia in an infrastructure is also covered.

Hydrogen storage technol. is essentially necessary to promote renewable energy. Many kinds of hydrogen storage materials, which are hydrogen storage alloys, inorg. chem. hydrides, carbon materials and liq. hydrides have been studied. In those materials, ammonia (NH3) is easily liquefied by compression at 1 MPa and 298 K, and has a highest volumetric hydrogen d. of 10.7 kg H2/100 L. It also has a high gravimetric hydrogen d. of 17.8 wt%. The theor. hydrogen conversion efficiency is about 90%. NH3 is burnable without emission of CO2 and has advantages as hydrogen and energy carriers.

Ammonia (NH3) has been proposed as a hydrogen (H2) carrier for energy services in the carbon-constrained future. This paper presents a technoeconomic feasibility study of using NH3 as H2 carrier for fuel cell vehicles (FCVs) applications. Two cases with different scales of anticipated operations: (1) centralized installation (1000 tonnes day-1) and (2) distributed refuelling station (500 kg day-1), were considered. Aspen HYSYS v8.6 was utilized to simulate the processes. The H2 prodn. cost, internal rate of return, payback period and net present value were examd. and compared. The results indicate the centralized H2 prodn. is both tech. and economically feasible while distributed H2 prodn., falling foul of economy of scale, is not economically viable. The overall H2 prodn. cost of the centralized H2 prodn. can reach as low as USD 5.50 kg-1 H2 accounting for capital expenditure, operating expenses, and decommissioning costs. The sensitivity anal. shown that the overall H2 prodn. cost is highly sensitive to NH3 price and moderately affected by utility price and various corporate tax rates considered.

A review. Catalytic decompn. of NH3 with complete conversion for generating H at low temp. (<450°) is getting much attention, as on-site H generation from NH3 bypasses the challenges of H storage and transportation. NH3 is a C-free H carrier with a reasonably good volumetric and gravimetric energy d. that has available technol. for efficient storage and transportation. The state-of-the-art catalysts for decompn. of NH3 are Ru doped with K, Ba and Cs and supported on various oxides and C supports; these catalysts are still not sufficiently active for low temp. NH3 decompn., and, more importantly, will not be economically viable for large-scale applications. This review provides a comprehensive consideration of recent development of various types of non-precious transition metal catalysts. Proposed mechanisms of NH3 decompn. on various transition metals are examd., and theor. bases for the design of future catalysts are presented, including the role of electronic promoters and supports. Among studied catalyst formulations, this review emphasizes transition metal nitride-Li imide composites where a synergy offers great promise for the efficient decompn. of NH3 at low temps. Development of such catalysts will make H storages, transportation, and generation from NH3 a feasible technol. for fuel cells and other energy applications.

A review. The possibility of using ammonia as a hydrogen carrier is discussed. Compared to other hydrogen storage materials, ammonia has the advantages of a high hydrogen d., a well-developed technol. for synthesis and distribution, and easy catalytic decompn. Compared to hydrocarbons and alcs., it has the advantage that there is no CO2 emission at the end user. The drawbacks are mainly the toxicity of liq. ammonia and the problems related to trace amts. of ammonia in the hydrogen after decompn. Storage of ammonia in metal ammine salts is discussed, and it is shown that this maintains the high volumetric hydrogen d. while alleviating the problems of handling the ammonia. Some of the remaining challenges for research in ammonia as a hydrogen carrier are outlined.

A review. In general, the post-combustion capture of CO2 is costly; however, swing adsorption processes can reduce these costs under certain conditions. This review highlights the issues related to adsorption-based processes for the capture of CO2 from flue gas. In particular, we consider studies that investigate CO2 adsorbents for vacuum swing or temp. swing adsorption processes. Zeolites, carbon mol. sieves, metal org. frameworks, microporous polymers, and amine-modified sorbents are relevant for such processes. The large-vol. gas flows in the gas flue stacks of power plants limit the possibilities of using regular swing adsorption processes, whose cycles are relatively slow. The structuring of CO2 adsorbents is crucial for the rapid swing cycles needed to capture CO2 at large point sources. We review the literature on such structured CO2 adsorbents. Impurities may impact the function of the sorbents, and could affect the overall thermodn. of power plants, when combined with carbon capture and storage. The heat integration of the adsorption-driven processes with the power plant is crucial in ensuring the economy of the capture of CO2, and impacts the design of both the adsorbents and the processes. The development of adsorbents with high capacity, high selectivity, rapid uptake, easy recycling, and suitable thermal and mech. properties is a challenging task. These tasks call for interdisciplinary studies addressing this delicate optimization process, including integration with the overall thermodn. of power plants.

The facile decompn. of ammonia to produce hydrogen is crit. to its use as a hydrogen storage medium in a hydrogen economy, and although ruthenium shows good activity for catalyzing this process, its expense and scarcity are prohibitive to large-scale commercialization. The need to develop alternative catalysts has been addressed here, using microkinetic modeling combined with d. functional studies to identify suitable monolayer bimetallic (surface or subsurface) catalysts based on binding energies. The Ni-Pt-Pt(111) surface, with one monolayer of Ni atoms residing on a Pt(111) substrate, was predicted to be a catalytically active surface. This was verified using temp.-programmed desorption and high-resoln. electron energy loss spectroscopy expts. The results reported here provide a framework for complex catalyst discovery. They also demonstrate the crit. importance of combining theor. and exptl. approaches for identifying desirable monolayer bimetallic systems when the surface properties are not a linear function of the parent metals.

The catalytic decompn. of ammonia has recently been proposed as a possible source of hydrogen for fuel cells. However, the ruthenium catalyst is costly. Although there exist several correlations for catalytic activity that suggest potentially useful alternatives, the particular candidates differ. The present work seeks to det. exptl. which, if any, of these correlations correctly predicts suitable substitutes. The expts. examine 13 different metallic catalysts from numerous places within the Periodic Table, and show that the activity varies in the order Ru>Ni>Rh>Co>Ir>Fe»Pt>Cr>Pd>Cu»Te, Se, Pb. The results suggest that nitrogen desorption limits the rate on Fe, Co, and Ni, whereas N-H bond scission limits the rate on other metals such as Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt, and Cu. Conventional single-parameter correlations of activity generally fail to predict the results because the rate-detg. step changes across the data set.

Supported nickel catalysts are widely used in the steam-reforming process for industrial scale prodn. of hydrogen and synthesis gas. This paper provides a study of sintering in nickel-based catalysts (Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4). Specifically the influence of time, temp., atm., nickel-carrier interactions and dopants on the rate of sintering is considered. To probe the sintering kinetics, all catalysts were analyzed by sulfur chemisorption to det. the Ni surface area. Also selected samples were further analyzed using XRD, mercury porosimetry, BET area measurements, and electron microscopy (EM). The obsd. sintering rates as a function of time, temp., and PH2O/PH2 ratio were consistent with recent model predictions [J. Sehested et. al., (2004)] over a broad range of environmental conditions. However, exposing the catalysts to severe sintering conditions, the loss of nickel surface area is faster than model predictions and the deviation is attributed to a change in the sintering mechanism and nickel removal by nickel-carrier interactions. Surprisingly, alumina-supported Ni particles grow to sizes larger than the particle size of the carrier indicating that the pore diam. does not represent an upper limit for Ni particle growth. The effects of potassium promotion and sulfur poisoning on the rates of sintering were also studied. No significant effects of the dopants were obsd. after aging at ambient pressure. However, at high pressures of steam and hydrogen (31 bar and H2O:H2 = 10:1) potassium promotion increased the sintering rate relative to that of the unpromoted catalyst. Sulfur also enhances the rate of sintering at high pressures, but the effect of sulfur is less than for potassium.

Deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts is a ubiquitous problem that causes loss of catalytic rate with time. This review on deactivation and regeneration of heterogeneous catalysts classifies deactivation by type (chem., thermal, and mech.) and by mechanism (poisoning, fouling, thermal degrdn., vapor formation, vapor-solid and solid-solid reactions, and attrition/crushing). The key features and considerations for each of these deactivation types is reviewed in detail with ref. to the latest literature reports in these areas. Two case studies on the deactivation mechanisms of catalysts used for cobalt Fischer-Tropsch and selective catalytic redn. are considered to provide addnl. depth in the topics of sintering, coking, poisoning, and fouling. Regeneration considerations and options are also briefly discussed for each deactivation mechanism.

Open-celled metal foams have been characterized as supports for structured catalysts, with consideration of their utilization in gas-solid catalytic processes with short contact times and high reaction rates, typically controlled by gas-solid diffusional mass transport. Examples of such processes are found in the field of environmental catalysis, including, e.g., catalytic combustion, selective catalytic redn. (SCR-DeNOx), and automotive exhaust gas aftertreatment. In this work, foams with different cell sizes were coated with a thin layer of palladium-alumina and tested in a 9-mm inner diam. tubular reactor by performing the catalytic oxidn. of CO at empty tube velocities in the range of 0.8-2.6 m/s. The coated foams exhibited sufficient catalytic activity to achieve mass-transfer-limited operation in the temp. range of 300-450°. Under such conditions, mass-transfer coeffs. were detd. according to a simple one-dimensional model of the test reactor. Adopting the av. diam. of the foam struts as the characteristic length, we obtained a dimensionless correlation for the estn. of mass-transfer coeffs. which correlates all the data: it closely resembles semitheoretical literature correlations for heat transfer in flow across banks of tubes at low Reynolds nos. Pressure drop measurements across foam samples were also collected for air velocities in the range of 1-16 m/s. The performances of foams, packed beds of pellets, and honeycomb monoliths as catalyst supports were compared on the basis of a dimensionless merit index, which accounts for the tradeoff between pressure drop and mass-transfer properties. Foams are largely superior to packed beds because of their high voidage, but perform slightly worse than honeycomb monoliths. On the other hand, foams can afford marked redns. of reactor vol. and wt., with respect to honeycombs, in fast, diffusion-controlled processes where pressure drop is of minor concern.

A review. CO2 methanation reaction has attracted renewed interest since the power-to-gas (PtG) concept emerged as a promising alternative for CO2 emission abatement using surplus renewable electricity. Although the reaction has been reported for more than a century, improvements in the catalytic system and reactor design remain challenging. Recently, hydrotalcite (HT) materials known for their facile synthesis and high performance are extensively used as precursors for supported catalysts in a wide range of reactions, including CO2 hydrogenation to CH4. Herein, a comprehensive overview on HT-derived catalysts applied for CO2 methanation is provided. More importantly, new reactor concepts are extensively investigated, such as honeycomb and microchannel reactors, to overcome issues related to the high exothermic nature of the reaction. The latest achievements with respect to structured reactors are also comprehensively reviewed and thoroughly discussed.

Carbon nanomaterials, such as carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers and graphene, featuring functional properties and tailored nanoscale dimensions have been widely used in different research fields, esp. for catalysis and sustainable chem. Hierarchically structured reactors, combining nanoscopic coating carbon layers to disperse the active phase or even directly as metal-free catalysts, with controlled macroscopic shapes, have been extensively developed over the last few decades for numerous relevant catalytic processes, where mass and heat transfer is easily optimized for better catalytic performance and stability. The 3D structuration enables the full exploitation of the intrinsic activity of the catalyst and its industrial deployment without drawbacks linked with nanomaterials. In this review article, we will summarize the recent developments involved in the field of hierarchically structured reactors, i.e. monoliths, foam and other materials, contg. carbon nanomaterials. It is expected that such structured reactors will receive high scientific and industrial interest in the future not only in the field of catalysis but also in those linked with wastewater purifn. or aerosol filtration processes. It will also be evidenced how hierarchically structured materials have contributed to the intensification of catalytic processes compared to conventional reactors, thus paving the way to the enhancement of other chem. reactions and their industrial deployment.

Water splitting is limited by the high theor. potential of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at anode, which can reduce the energy efficiency. Nevertheless, replacing sluggish oxygen evolution by ammonia oxidn. reaction (AOR), urea oxidn. reaction (UOR), hydrazine oxidn. reaction (HzOR) of low theor. potential is an energy-saving approach. In this paper, a new bifunctional catalyst of N doped NiZnCu-layered double hydroxides with reduced graphene oxide on nickel foam (N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO) is synthesized. To validate its electrochem. performance and stability, a two-electrode electrolyzer is constructed (N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO||N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO). Expts. show that at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2, the voltages of AOR, UOR, and HzOR are 0.489 V, 1.305 V, and 0.010 V with a high stability (over 3000 CV cycles), which are much better than those of Pt/C||IrO2. This study demonstrates N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO can replace precious metals for com. hydrogen energy prodn. in the hybrid-water electrolysis, and can be employed for treatment of industrial wastewater.

The cross-sectional analyses showed that the alloy structures of the heat-treated powders exist in a single-phase or core-shell form, depending on the no. of cryst. phase compns. predicted from the phase diagram. Addnl., the catalyst undergoing post-annealing at 400 °C achieved superior performance in both initial activity and durability, due to the adhesion layer of Ni2Al3 formed between the outermost catalytic layer and the nickel substrate. An in-situ sintered Ni-5 wt.% Al alloy anode for high-temp. fuel cells (HTFCs) was fabricated successfully using a green sheet consisting of a phys. mixt. of inexpensive Ni and Al elemental powders at reduced temps. Two processes-the formation of Ni-Al alloy via the AlCl3 activator under flowing hydrogen gas and the sintering of Ni-Al-occurred at the same time during pretreatment for cell operation. The AlCl3 activator reduced the synthesis reaction temp. and sintering temp. of Ni-Al alloy to nearly 600 °C. A two-phase alloy of a Ni3Al intermetallic compd. and a Ni-Al solid soln. was obtained after sintering at 600 °C. The creep resistance of the in-situ sintered Ni-5 wt.% Al alloy was better than that of the conventional Ni-Al alloy green sheet, even though the sintering temp. of the Ni-5 wt.% Al alloy was 600 °C. This novel prepn. method for Ni-Al alloys can greatly reduce the cost of anode fabrication for HTFCs and in turn accelerate the commercialization of HTFCs.

Open-cell porous metals have many applications due to high surface area to vol. ratios. Porous metals manufd. by the space holder methods have distinctively different porous structure from com. open-cell metal foams, but little research was conducted to characterize the surface area of this class of materials. This paper measured the geometric, electroactive and real surface areas of porous Cu samples manufd. by the Lost Carbonate Sintering process by quant. stereol. and cyclic voltammetry. A cyclic voltammetry (peak current) procedure was developed and successfully applied to the measurement of electroactive surface areas of the porous Cu. For porous Cu samples with pore sizes 75-1500 μm and porosities 0.5-0.8, the volumetric and gravimetric specific geometric, electroactive and real surface areas are in the ranges of 15-90 cm-1 and 5-45 cm2/g, 200-400 cm-1 and 40-130 cm2/g, and 1000-2500 cm-1 and 400-800 cm2/g, resp., varying with pore size and porosity. The geometric, electroactive and real surface areas are found to result from the contributions from primary porosity, primary and secondary porosities, and surfaces of metal particles, resp. The measurement methods adopted in this study can provide vital information of surface areas at different length scales, which is important for many applications.

In this work, the interface characteristics and resulting bond strength were investigated for roll bonded steel-aluminum composites with nickel interlayers, both after rolling and after post-rolling heat treatments at 400 °C-550 °C. After rolling, only mech. interlocking was achieved between the steel and nickel layers, which resulted in delamination. Post-rolling heat treatments resulted in sufficient metallurgical bonding between the steel and nickel layers, and a significant increase in the bond strength. An intermetallic phase layer formed during the heat treatments, which below 500 °C consisted of Al3Ni and above, Al3Ni and Al3Ni2. With increasing temp. and time, the Al3Ni2 phase consumed the Al3Ni layer, voids developed along the Al3Ni2-aluminum interface, and a duplex morphol. developed inside the Al3Ni2 layer, in accordance with the Kirkendall effect. The highest bond strength was obtained for the composites that only had an Al3Ni layer along the interface, and the optimal thickness was found to be 3-5 μm. The bond strength decreased with increasing temp. and time, due to increasing Al-Ni layer thickness, an increase in the fraction of Al3Ni2 relative to Al3Ni, and the development of voids. The results show that nickel can be used as an interlayer in steel-aluminum joints, and a high bond strength can be obtained through post-rolling heat treatments.

Three different Ni-Al foams were synthesized by vapor aluminizing with control of aluminizing time. Oxidn. tests under 1100°C and compression tests were conducted to evaluate the oxidn. resistance and compression properties of the foams. X-ray diffraction (XRD), SEM (SEM), and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) tests were carried out to study the phase compn. and microstructure of Ni-Al foams before and after oxidn. Results showed that vapor aluminizing process did not change the foam macro- and microstructure, and the phase compn. became from β/γ'-phase to single β-phase as the aluminizing time extending. The Ni-Al foams possessed excellent oxidn. resistance, and decreased Al content increased oxidn. wt. gain and altered oxidn. products. Foams contg. single β-phase presented obvious brittleness under compression tests, but the foam with β/γ'-phase exhibited elasticity and toughness to a certain extent. The elasticity and toughness of the foams significantly can be improved after oxidn. because of the phase changing in matrix during oxidn., and the pre-oxidized high-Al-content Ni-Al foams exhibited good compression properties, as well as excellent oxidn. resistance.

Apparent Activation Energies in Complex Reaction Mechanisms: A Simple Relationship via Degrees of Rate Control
Mao, Zhongtian; Campbell, Charles T.
ACS Catalysis
(
2019
),
9
(
10
),
9465-9473
CODEN:

; ISSN:
2155-5435
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The apparent activation energy of chem. reactions has played a central role in the field of chem. kinetics and has served as an important tool for analyzing and understanding reaction rates, mechanistic details of complex reaction mechanisms, elementary-step energetics, catalytic activity and reaction selectivity. We derive here a general expression which shows that the apparent activation energy equals a weighted av. of the std.-state enthalpies (relative to reactants) of all the species (intermediates, transition states and products) in the reaction mechanism, each weighted by its generalized degree of rate control (DRC). Since the DRC is zero for most of these species, even in very complex mechanisms, the weighted av. includes only a few terms. This simplicity provides deep insight into the connection between the reaction energy diagram and the apparent activation energy. We prove both this and the quant. validity of this equation by anal. of numerous reaction mechanisms. We also show the failures or weaknesses of previous equations for the apparent activation energy.

Catalytic decompn. of ammonia has been investigated as a method to produce hydrogen for fuel cell applications. The absence of any undesirable byproducts (unlike, e.g., COx, formed during reforming of hydrocarbons and alcs.) makes this process an ideal source of hydrogen for fuel cells. In this study a variety of supported metal catalysts have been studied. Supported Ru catalysts were the most active, whereas supported Ni catalysts were the least active. The supports played a profound role in the ammonia decompn. process. The activation energies for the ammonia decompn. process varied from 17 to 22 kcal/mol depending upon the catalyst employed. The activation energies of the supported Ir catalysts were in excellent agreement with recent studies addressing ammonia decompn. on single crystal Ir.

The starting alloys were prepd. by gas atomization or cast and crush process and subsequently activated by a conventional leaching process. The aim was to study the influence of the phase compn. and the effect of the initial particle size of the alloys on the catalytic performance. Advantages of the atomization process over the traditional cast and crush process are demonstrated.

Selecting a proper support in the catalyst system plays an important role in hydrogen prodn. via ethanol steam reforming. In this study, sol gel made alumina supports prepd. for nickel (Ni) catalysts were calcined at different temps. A series of (Ni/AlS.G.) catalysts were synthesized by an impregnation procedure. The influence of varying the calcination temp. of the sol gel made supports on catalyst activity was tested in ethanol reforming reaction. The characteristics of the sol gel alumina supports and Ni catalysts were affected by the calcination temp. of the supports. The structure of the sol gel made alumina supports was transformed in the order of γ → (γ + ) → -alumina as the calcination temp. of the supports increased from 600 °C to 1000 °C. Both hydrogen yield and ethanol conversion presented a volcano-shaped behavior with max. values of 4.3 mol/mol ethanol fed and 99.5%, resp. The optimum values were exhibited over Ni/AlS.G800 (Ni catalyst supported on sol gel made alumina calcined at 800 °C). The high performance of the Ni/AlS.G800 catalyst may be attributed to the strong interaction of Ni species and sol gel made alumina which lead to high nickel dispersion and small particle size.

Alloying provides a means by which to tune a metal catalyst's electronic structure and thus tailor its performance; however, mean-field behavior in metals imposes limits. To access unprecedented catalytic behavior, materials must exhibit emergent properties that are not simply interpolations of the constituent components' properties. Here we show an emergent electronic structure in single-atom alloys, whereby weak wavefunction mixing between minority and majority elements results in a free-atom-like electronic structure on the minority element. This unusual electronic structure alters the minority element's adsorption properties such that the bonding with adsorbates resembles the bonding in mol. metal complexes. We demonstrate this phenomenon with AgCu alloys, dil. in Cu, where the Cu d states are nearly unperturbed from their free-atom state. In situ electron spectroscopy demonstrates that this unusual electronic structure persists in reaction conditions and exhibits a 0.1 eV smaller activation barrier than bulk Cu in methanol reforming. Theory predicts that several other dil. alloys exhibit this phenomenon, which offers a design approach that may lead to alloys with unprecedented catalytic properties.

Pd and its alloys play a central role in industrial applications such as H reactions, sepns., storage devices, and as fuel cell components. Alloy compns. are complex and often heterogeneous at the at.-scale and the exact mechanisms by which many of these processes operate have yet to be discovered. Herein, scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) was used to study the at.-scale structure of Pd-Au and Pd-Cu bimetallics created by depositing Pd on both Au(111) and Cu(111) single crystals at a variety of surface temps. Individual, isolated Pd atoms in an inert Cu matrix are active for the dissocn. of H and subsequent spillover onto Cu sites. H spillover was facile on Pd-Cu at 420 K but no H was found under the same H2 flux on a Pd-Au sample with identical at. compn. and geometry. In the case of Au, significant H uptake was only obsd. when larger ensembles of Pd were present as nanoparticles. The authors report exptl. evidence for H's ability to reverse the tendency of Pd to segregate into the Au surface at catalytically relevant temps. and the STM images reveal a novel H-induced striped structure in which Pd atoms aggregated on top of the surface in regularly spaced rows. These results demonstrate the powerful influence an inert substrate has on the catalytic activity of Pd atoms supported in or on its surface and reveal how the at.-scale geometry of Pd-Au alloys is greatly affected by the presence of H.

Ni/Al2O3, Ni/MgAlO, and Ni/MgO catalysts were studied for the hydrogenation of pyridine to piperidine. Microcalorimetric adsorption and IR spectroscopy were used to study the adsorption of CO, H2, pyridine, and piperidine on the catalysts. It was found that the basic support (MgO) increased the heat of adsorption of CO on Ni, due to the increased surface electron d. of Ni, while weakened the strength of H-Ni, which might be a reason for the decreased activity of Ni/MgO for the hydrogenation of pyridine. In contrast, the acidic support (Al2O3) caused the electron-deficient surface metallic Ni that enhanced the adsorption of H2 and pyridine and thus favored the hydrogenation of pyridine. In addn., it was found that pyridine was more strongly adsorbed on Ni than piperidine although piperidine is a stronger base than pyridine, indicating that the electron-enriched arom. ring of pyridine might be involved in the adsorption of pyridine on Ni, which was favored on the electron-deficient surface Ni and acidic support.

Of the catalysts examd., Ni_MgAl(6:1) exhibited the highest NH3 conversion, which was attributed to its relatively high basicity and large amt. of Ni0 exposed.

Ammonia (NH3) has been proposed as a hydrogen (H2) carrier for energy services in the carbon-constrained future. This paper presents a technoeconomic feasibility study of using NH3 as H2 carrier for fuel cell vehicles (FCVs) applications. Two cases with different scales of anticipated operations: (1) centralized installation (1000 tonnes day-1) and (2) distributed refuelling station (500 kg day-1), were considered. Aspen HYSYS v8.6 was utilized to simulate the processes. The H2 prodn. cost, internal rate of return, payback period and net present value were examd. and compared. The results indicate the centralized H2 prodn. is both tech. and economically feasible while distributed H2 prodn., falling foul of economy of scale, is not economically viable. The overall H2 prodn. cost of the centralized H2 prodn. can reach as low as USD 5.50 kg-1 H2 accounting for capital expenditure, operating expenses, and decommissioning costs. The sensitivity anal. shown that the overall H2 prodn. cost is highly sensitive to NH3 price and moderately affected by utility price and various corporate tax rates considered.

A review. Catalytic decompn. of NH3 with complete conversion for generating H at low temp. (<450°) is getting much attention, as on-site H generation from NH3 bypasses the challenges of H storage and transportation. NH3 is a C-free H carrier with a reasonably good volumetric and gravimetric energy d. that has available technol. for efficient storage and transportation. The state-of-the-art catalysts for decompn. of NH3 are Ru doped with K, Ba and Cs and supported on various oxides and C supports; these catalysts are still not sufficiently active for low temp. NH3 decompn., and, more importantly, will not be economically viable for large-scale applications. This review provides a comprehensive consideration of recent development of various types of non-precious transition metal catalysts. Proposed mechanisms of NH3 decompn. on various transition metals are examd., and theor. bases for the design of future catalysts are presented, including the role of electronic promoters and supports. Among studied catalyst formulations, this review emphasizes transition metal nitride-Li imide composites where a synergy offers great promise for the efficient decompn. of NH3 at low temps. Development of such catalysts will make H storages, transportation, and generation from NH3 a feasible technol. for fuel cells and other energy applications.

A review. The possibility of using ammonia as a hydrogen carrier is discussed. Compared to other hydrogen storage materials, ammonia has the advantages of a high hydrogen d., a well-developed technol. for synthesis and distribution, and easy catalytic decompn. Compared to hydrocarbons and alcs., it has the advantage that there is no CO2 emission at the end user. The drawbacks are mainly the toxicity of liq. ammonia and the problems related to trace amts. of ammonia in the hydrogen after decompn. Storage of ammonia in metal ammine salts is discussed, and it is shown that this maintains the high volumetric hydrogen d. while alleviating the problems of handling the ammonia. Some of the remaining challenges for research in ammonia as a hydrogen carrier are outlined.

Hedin, Niklas; Andersson, Linnea; Bergstroem, Lennart; Yan, Jinyue

A review. In general, the post-combustion capture of CO2 is costly; however, swing adsorption processes can reduce these costs under certain conditions. This review highlights the issues related to adsorption-based processes for the capture of CO2 from flue gas. In particular, we consider studies that investigate CO2 adsorbents for vacuum swing or temp. swing adsorption processes. Zeolites, carbon mol. sieves, metal org. frameworks, microporous polymers, and amine-modified sorbents are relevant for such processes. The large-vol. gas flows in the gas flue stacks of power plants limit the possibilities of using regular swing adsorption processes, whose cycles are relatively slow. The structuring of CO2 adsorbents is crucial for the rapid swing cycles needed to capture CO2 at large point sources. We review the literature on such structured CO2 adsorbents. Impurities may impact the function of the sorbents, and could affect the overall thermodn. of power plants, when combined with carbon capture and storage. The heat integration of the adsorption-driven processes with the power plant is crucial in ensuring the economy of the capture of CO2, and impacts the design of both the adsorbents and the processes. The development of adsorbents with high capacity, high selectivity, rapid uptake, easy recycling, and suitable thermal and mech. properties is a challenging task. These tasks call for interdisciplinary studies addressing this delicate optimization process, including integration with the overall thermodn. of power plants.

The facile decompn. of ammonia to produce hydrogen is crit. to its use as a hydrogen storage medium in a hydrogen economy, and although ruthenium shows good activity for catalyzing this process, its expense and scarcity are prohibitive to large-scale commercialization. The need to develop alternative catalysts has been addressed here, using microkinetic modeling combined with d. functional studies to identify suitable monolayer bimetallic (surface or subsurface) catalysts based on binding energies. The Ni-Pt-Pt(111) surface, with one monolayer of Ni atoms residing on a Pt(111) substrate, was predicted to be a catalytically active surface. This was verified using temp.-programmed desorption and high-resoln. electron energy loss spectroscopy expts. The results reported here provide a framework for complex catalyst discovery. They also demonstrate the crit. importance of combining theor. and exptl. approaches for identifying desirable monolayer bimetallic systems when the surface properties are not a linear function of the parent metals.

Ceria-supported Ni, Ru and Ni-Ru catalysts have been tested in the catalytic decompn. of ammonia to yield hydrogen and their performance in long-term tests has been compared to alumina-supported Ni and Ru samples. The catalysts have been characterized by XRD, TPR, NH3-TPD, HAADF-STEM, SEM, BET and XPS. Ceria-based samples are more active in ammonia decompn. with respect to their alumina-based counterparts, which has been ascribed to a particular metal-support interaction, while acidity does not seem to play an important role. Ru-based catalysts are more active than Ni-based samples, but they deactivate rapidly, in particular the Ru/Al2O3 sample. This is ascribed to loss of exposed Ru, as demonstrated by XPS and HAADF-STEM. Considering the high cost and limited availability of Ru, the Ni/CeO2 catalyst appears as a promising system for ammonia decompn. due to its good performance and low cost. In situ XPS expts. reveal that the active sites for the catalytic decompn. of ammonia are metallic Ni and Ru. Bimetallic Ni-Ru catalysts do not outperform their monometallic counterparts, irresp. of the order in which the metals are added.

A wet impregnation method is used to synthesize Ni nanocatalysts supported on naturally abundant mica nanosheets for decompn. of ammonia to COx-free hydrogen. The prepd. catalysts are characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, N2 sorption, TG, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3/H2-TPD techniques. The catalytic tests exhibit that the Ni/mica catalysts are highly active for ammonia decompn. The two-dimensional structure of mica favors mass transportation, which can remarkably promote the catalytic process. The NH3/H2-TPD curves of Ni/mica show no desorption signals of NH3 and H2, indicating the presence of weak desorption energy barrier. The content of Ni in the catalysts is related to the crystallite size of Ni species, affecting their catalytic properties. As demonstrated in this study, the Ni/mica catalyst with 15% Ni loading amt. exhibits the highest catalytic activity and long-term stability. At a high space velocity of 30000 cm3 g-1cat h-1, 97.2% ammonia conversion is achieved over the 15%Ni/mica catalyst at 650 °C, indicating the Ni/mica is a promising catalyst for ammonia decompn.

The catalytic decompn. of ammonia has recently been proposed as a possible source of hydrogen for fuel cells. However, the ruthenium catalyst is costly. Although there exist several correlations for catalytic activity that suggest potentially useful alternatives, the particular candidates differ. The present work seeks to det. exptl. which, if any, of these correlations correctly predicts suitable substitutes. The expts. examine 13 different metallic catalysts from numerous places within the Periodic Table, and show that the activity varies in the order Ru>Ni>Rh>Co>Ir>Fe»Pt>Cr>Pd>Cu»Te, Se, Pb. The results suggest that nitrogen desorption limits the rate on Fe, Co, and Ni, whereas N-H bond scission limits the rate on other metals such as Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt, and Cu. Conventional single-parameter correlations of activity generally fail to predict the results because the rate-detg. step changes across the data set.
