Supported nickel catalysts are widely used in the steam-reforming process for industrial scale prodn. of hydrogen and synthesis gas. This paper provides a study of sintering in nickel-based catalysts (Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl2O4). Specifically the influence of time, temp., atm., nickel-carrier interactions and dopants on the rate of sintering is considered. To probe the sintering kinetics, all catalysts were analyzed by sulfur chemisorption to det. the Ni surface area. Also selected samples were further analyzed using XRD, mercury porosimetry, BET area measurements, and electron microscopy (EM). The obsd. sintering rates as a function of time, temp., and PH2O/PH2 ratio were consistent with recent model predictions [J. Sehested et. al., (2004)] over a broad range of environmental conditions. However, exposing the catalysts to severe sintering conditions, the loss of nickel surface area is faster than model predictions and the deviation is attributed to a change in the sintering mechanism and nickel removal by nickel-carrier interactions. Surprisingly, alumina-supported Ni particles grow to sizes larger than the particle size of the carrier indicating that the pore diam. does not represent an upper limit for Ni particle growth. The effects of potassium promotion and sulfur poisoning on the rates of sintering were also studied. No significant effects of the dopants were obsd. after aging at ambient pressure. However, at high pressures of steam and hydrogen (31 bar and H2O:H2 = 10:1) potassium promotion increased the sintering rate relative to that of the unpromoted catalyst. Sulfur also enhances the rate of sintering at high pressures, but the effect of sulfur is less than for potassium.

Deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts is a ubiquitous problem that causes loss of catalytic rate with time. This review on deactivation and regeneration of heterogeneous catalysts classifies deactivation by type (chem., thermal, and mech.) and by mechanism (poisoning, fouling, thermal degrdn., vapor formation, vapor-solid and solid-solid reactions, and attrition/crushing). The key features and considerations for each of these deactivation types is reviewed in detail with ref. to the latest literature reports in these areas. Two case studies on the deactivation mechanisms of catalysts used for cobalt Fischer-Tropsch and selective catalytic redn. are considered to provide addnl. depth in the topics of sintering, coking, poisoning, and fouling. Regeneration considerations and options are also briefly discussed for each deactivation mechanism.

Modifying the material structure of catalysts and detg. how the structure controls their catalytic activities are crit. topics in heterogeneous catalysis research. Herein we report that the structure of hydrocalumite-layered double hydroxides (CaAl-LDHs) can be tuned by gradually introducting Ni2+. It was revealed that the gradual introduction of Ni2+ in hydrocalumite led to a structure-transformation process, which introduced hydrombobomkulite and eventually evolved into takovite. Compared with the case without structure-transformation process, the structure-transformation catalysts showed excellent NH3 decompn. activity after high-temp. redn. Moreover, the obtained catalysts showed a relatively high conversion per Ni wt. compared with other reported oxide-supported Ni catalysts. This study demonstrates the feasibility of prepg. LDHs-based heterogeneous catalysts by modulating the material structure through induced structure-transformation process.

Open-celled metal foams have been characterized as supports for structured catalysts, with consideration of their utilization in gas-solid catalytic processes with short contact times and high reaction rates, typically controlled by gas-solid diffusional mass transport. Examples of such processes are found in the field of environmental catalysis, including, e.g., catalytic combustion, selective catalytic redn. (SCR-DeNOx), and automotive exhaust gas aftertreatment. In this work, foams with different cell sizes were coated with a thin layer of palladium-alumina and tested in a 9-mm inner diam. tubular reactor by performing the catalytic oxidn. of CO at empty tube velocities in the range of 0.8-2.6 m/s. The coated foams exhibited sufficient catalytic activity to achieve mass-transfer-limited operation in the temp. range of 300-450°. Under such conditions, mass-transfer coeffs. were detd. according to a simple one-dimensional model of the test reactor. Adopting the av. diam. of the foam struts as the characteristic length, we obtained a dimensionless correlation for the estn. of mass-transfer coeffs. which correlates all the data: it closely resembles semitheoretical literature correlations for heat transfer in flow across banks of tubes at low Reynolds nos. Pressure drop measurements across foam samples were also collected for air velocities in the range of 1-16 m/s. The performances of foams, packed beds of pellets, and honeycomb monoliths as catalyst supports were compared on the basis of a dimensionless merit index, which accounts for the tradeoff between pressure drop and mass-transfer properties. Foams are largely superior to packed beds because of their high voidage, but perform slightly worse than honeycomb monoliths. On the other hand, foams can afford marked redns. of reactor vol. and wt., with respect to honeycombs, in fast, diffusion-controlled processes where pressure drop is of minor concern.

A review. CO2 methanation reaction has attracted renewed interest since the power-to-gas (PtG) concept emerged as a promising alternative for CO2 emission abatement using surplus renewable electricity. Although the reaction has been reported for more than a century, improvements in the catalytic system and reactor design remain challenging. Recently, hydrotalcite (HT) materials known for their facile synthesis and high performance are extensively used as precursors for supported catalysts in a wide range of reactions, including CO2 hydrogenation to CH4. Herein, a comprehensive overview on HT-derived catalysts applied for CO2 methanation is provided. More importantly, new reactor concepts are extensively investigated, such as honeycomb and microchannel reactors, to overcome issues related to the high exothermic nature of the reaction. The latest achievements with respect to structured reactors are also comprehensively reviewed and thoroughly discussed.

Hierarchically structured reactors containing nanocarbons for intensification of chemical reactions

Carbon nanomaterials, such as carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers and graphene, featuring functional properties and tailored nanoscale dimensions have been widely used in different research fields, esp. for catalysis and sustainable chem. Hierarchically structured reactors, combining nanoscopic coating carbon layers to disperse the active phase or even directly as metal-free catalysts, with controlled macroscopic shapes, have been extensively developed over the last few decades for numerous relevant catalytic processes, where mass and heat transfer is easily optimized for better catalytic performance and stability. The 3D structuration enables the full exploitation of the intrinsic activity of the catalyst and its industrial deployment without drawbacks linked with nanomaterials. In this review article, we will summarize the recent developments involved in the field of hierarchically structured reactors, i.e. monoliths, foam and other materials, contg. carbon nanomaterials. It is expected that such structured reactors will receive high scientific and industrial interest in the future not only in the field of catalysis but also in those linked with wastewater purifn. or aerosol filtration processes. It will also be evidenced how hierarchically structured materials have contributed to the intensification of catalytic processes compared to conventional reactors, thus paving the way to the enhancement of other chem. reactions and their industrial deployment.

Direct growth of graphene on metal surface opens a door for obtaining high-performance composites in a simple way. In order to obtain both high strength and enhanced damping property of porous metal, we prepd. graphene-coated nickel hybrid foams by chem. vapor deposition technique, and investigated the static and dynamic mech. properties using a dynamic mech. analyzer and vibration testing systems in detail. We found that the presence of graphene layers could greatly improve both mech. strength and damping properties of nickel foams. The graphene-coated nickel hybrid foams exhibited high yield strength, compressive modulus and damping ratio, increased by 46 %, 22 % and 53 % in comparison with those of nickel foams. Such significant graphene-reinforcement in mech. and damping properties is mainly attributed to the strong interfacial bonding, remarkable confinement effect, and rich interfaces in hybrid foams. By virtue of its high mech. strength and enhanced damping properties, the graphene/nickel hybrid foams have great potential to be used as multi-functional composite materials in many fields.

Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) involves multiple electron-transfer processes, resulting in a high activation barrier. Developing catalysts with low overpotential and high intrinsic activity toward OER is crit. but challenging. Here we report a major advancement in decreasing the overpotential for oxygen evolution reaction. Ni foam-supported Fe-doped β-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets achieve an overpotential of 219 mV at the geometric c.d. of 10 mA cm-2. To our knowledge, this is the best value reported for Ni- or Fe hydroxide-based OER catalysts. In addn., the catalyst yields a c.d. of 6.25 mA cm-2 at the overpotential of 300 mV when it is normalized to the electrochem. surface area of the catalyst. This intrinsic catalytic activity is also better than the values reported for most state-of-the-art OER catalysts at the same overpotential.

Water splitting is limited by the high theor. potential of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at anode, which can reduce the energy efficiency. Nevertheless, replacing sluggish oxygen evolution by ammonia oxidn. reaction (AOR), urea oxidn. reaction (UOR), hydrazine oxidn. reaction (HzOR) of low theor. potential is an energy-saving approach. In this paper, a new bifunctional catalyst of N doped NiZnCu-layered double hydroxides with reduced graphene oxide on nickel foam (N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO) is synthesized. To validate its electrochem. performance and stability, a two-electrode electrolyzer is constructed (N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO||N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO). Expts. show that at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2, the voltages of AOR, UOR, and HzOR are 0.489 V, 1.305 V, and 0.010 V with a high stability (over 3000 CV cycles), which are much better than those of Pt/C||IrO2. This study demonstrates N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO can replace precious metals for com. hydrogen energy prodn. in the hybrid-water electrolysis, and can be employed for treatment of industrial wastewater.

Micro-sized Ni-Al alloy powders were synthesized using different quantities of Ni and Al powders as well as AlCl3 as an activator in a quartz batch reactor at ≤773 K. This method, named low-temp. chem. alloying (LTCA), which allows Al atoms to diffuse into micro-sized nickel particles mediated by aluminum chloride (chem. promotor), is distinct from conventional processes, such as cast-and-crush, and gas atomization. As-synthesized Ni-Al alloys were characterized using different anal. techniques that included X-ray diffraction (XRD), particle size anal., and field emission SEM in conjunction with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (FESEM-EDS), to confirm the formation of alloy phases, such as Ni3Al, NiAl, Ni2Al3, and NiAl3. The anal. results showed that the cryst. phase compns. of the Ni-Al alloys were highly dependent upon the initial amts. of Ni and Al powders employed at the given alloying conditions (alloying temp., 773 K; alloying time, 20 h; amt. of AlCl3, 1.2 wt%). As a result of the thermal treatment of Ni-Al powder mixts. with the Al contents of (5, 15, 30, and 50) wt.% under continuous powder mixing by rotation, each powder was found to have (i) Ni solid soln. + Ni3Al, (ii) Ni3Al, (iii) NiAl, and (iv) Ni2Al3 + NiAl3 phases, resp., corresponding to the equil. states of the Ni-Al phase diagram. The cross-sectional analyses showed that the alloy structures of the heat-treated powders exist in a single-phase or core-shell form, depending on the no. of cryst. phase compns. predicted from the phase diagram. In particular, the Ni-50 wt% Al powder has a unique
[email protected]
core-shell structure. We further evaluate the performance of the as-developed Ni-Al alloy powders as oxidn.-resistant materials and template materials for high-surface area (∼60 m2/gcat) nickel catalysts.

Open-cell porous metals have many applications due to high surface area to vol. ratios. Porous metals manufd. by the space holder methods have distinctively different porous structure from com. open-cell metal foams, but little research was conducted to characterize the surface area of this class of materials. This paper measured the geometric, electroactive and real surface areas of porous Cu samples manufd. by the Lost Carbonate Sintering process by quant. stereol. and cyclic voltammetry. A cyclic voltammetry (peak current) procedure was developed and successfully applied to the measurement of electroactive surface areas of the porous Cu. For porous Cu samples with pore sizes 75-1500 μm and porosities 0.5-0.8, the volumetric and gravimetric specific geometric, electroactive and real surface areas are in the ranges of 15-90 cm-1 and 5-45 cm2/g, 200-400 cm-1 and 40-130 cm2/g, and 1000-2500 cm-1 and 400-800 cm2/g, resp., varying with pore size and porosity. The geometric, electroactive and real surface areas are found to result from the contributions from primary porosity, primary and secondary porosities, and surfaces of metal particles, resp. The measurement methods adopted in this study can provide vital information of surface areas at different length scales, which is important for many applications.

In this work, the interface characteristics and resulting bond strength were investigated for roll bonded steel-aluminum composites with nickel interlayers, both after rolling and after post-rolling heat treatments at 400 °C-550 °C. After rolling, only mech. interlocking was achieved between the steel and nickel layers, which resulted in delamination. Post-rolling heat treatments resulted in sufficient metallurgical bonding between the steel and nickel layers, and a significant increase in the bond strength. An intermetallic phase layer formed during the heat treatments, which below 500 °C consisted of Al3Ni and above, Al3Ni and Al3Ni2. With increasing temp. and time, the Al3Ni2 phase consumed the Al3Ni layer, voids developed along the Al3Ni2-aluminum interface, and a duplex morphol. developed inside the Al3Ni2 layer, in accordance with the Kirkendall effect. The highest bond strength was obtained for the composites that only had an Al3Ni layer along the interface, and the optimal thickness was found to be 3-5 μm. The bond strength decreased with increasing temp. and time, due to increasing Al-Ni layer thickness, an increase in the fraction of Al3Ni2 relative to Al3Ni, and the development of voids. The results show that nickel can be used as an interlayer in steel-aluminum joints, and a high bond strength can be obtained through post-rolling heat treatments.

Three different Ni-Al foams were synthesized by vapor aluminizing with control of aluminizing time. Oxidn. tests under 1100°C and compression tests were conducted to evaluate the oxidn. resistance and compression properties of the foams. X-ray diffraction (XRD), SEM (SEM), and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) tests were carried out to study the phase compn. and microstructure of Ni-Al foams before and after oxidn. Results showed that vapor aluminizing process did not change the foam macro- and microstructure, and the phase compn. became from β/γ'-phase to single β-phase as the aluminizing time extending. The Ni-Al foams possessed excellent oxidn. resistance, and decreased Al content increased oxidn. wt. gain and altered oxidn. products. Foams contg. single β-phase presented obvious brittleness under compression tests, but the foam with β/γ'-phase exhibited elasticity and toughness to a certain extent. The elasticity and toughness of the foams significantly can be improved after oxidn. because of the phase changing in matrix during oxidn., and the pre-oxidized high-Al-content Ni-Al foams exhibited good compression properties, as well as excellent oxidn. resistance.

Apparent Activation Energies in Complex Reaction Mechanisms: A Simple Relationship via Degrees of Rate Control
Mao, Zhongtian; Campbell, Charles T.
ACS Catalysis
(

(

; ISSN:

American Chemical Society

The apparent activation energy of chem. reactions has played a central role in the field of chem. kinetics and has served as an important tool for analyzing and understanding reaction rates, mechanistic details of complex reaction mechanisms, elementary-step energetics, catalytic activity and reaction selectivity. We derive here a general expression which shows that the apparent activation energy equals a weighted av. of the std.-state enthalpies (relative to reactants) of all the species (intermediates, transition states and products) in the reaction mechanism, each weighted by its generalized degree of rate control (DRC). Since the DRC is zero for most of these species, even in very complex mechanisms, the weighted av. includes only a few terms. This simplicity provides deep insight into the connection between the reaction energy diagram and the apparent activation energy. We prove both this and the quant. validity of this equation by anal. of numerous reaction mechanisms. We also show the failures or weaknesses of previous equations for the apparent activation energy.

Catalytic decompn. of ammonia has been investigated as a method to produce hydrogen for fuel cell applications. The absence of any undesirable byproducts (unlike, e.g., COx, formed during reforming of hydrocarbons and alcs.) makes this process an ideal source of hydrogen for fuel cells. In this study a variety of supported metal catalysts have been studied. Supported Ru catalysts were the most active, whereas supported Ni catalysts were the least active. The supports played a profound role in the ammonia decompn. process. The activation energies for the ammonia decompn. process varied from 17 to 22 kcal/mol depending upon the catalyst employed. The activation energies of the supported Ir catalysts were in excellent agreement with recent studies addressing ammonia decompn. on single crystal Ir.

The influence of varying the calcination temp. of the sol gel made supports on catalyst activity was tested in ethanol reforming reaction. Alloying provides a means by which to tune a metal catalyst's electronic structure and thus tailor its performance; however, mean-field behavior in metals imposes limits. To access unprecedented catalytic behavior, materials must exhibit emergent properties that are not simply interpolations of the constituent components' properties. Here we show an emergent electronic structure in single-atom alloys, whereby weak wavefunction mixing between minority and majority elements results in a free-atom-like electronic structure on the minority element. This unusual electronic structure alters the minority element's adsorption properties such that the bonding with adsorbates resembles the bonding in mol. metal complexes. We demonstrate this phenomenon with AgCu alloys, dil. in Cu, where the Cu d states are nearly unperturbed from their free-atom state. In situ electron spectroscopy demonstrates that this unusual electronic structure persists in reaction conditions and exhibits a 0.1 eV smaller activation barrier than bulk Cu in methanol reforming. Theory predicts that several other dil. alloys exhibit this phenomenon, which offers a design approach that may lead to alloys with unprecedented catalytic properties.

.
(
MDPI AG
)
The Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst, which was prepd. by in situ temp.-program redn. and in the mixt. with the inert (SiC, SiO2) or acidic (γ-Al2O3) material was studied in Me palmitate hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). Me palmitate HDO was carried out at temps. of 270-330 °C, H2/feed vol. ratio of 600 Nm3/m3, and H2 pressure of 3.0 MPa. Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst, dild. with γ-Al2O3 showed a higher activity than Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst dild. with SiC or SiO2. The conversion of Me palmitate increased significantly in the presence of γ-Al2O3 most probably due to the acceleration of the acid-catalyzed reaction of ester hydrolysis. The synergism of Ni2P/SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 in Me palmitate HDO can be explained by the cooperation of the metal sites of Ni2P/SiO2 and the acid sites of γ-Al2O3 in consecutive metal-catalyzed and acid-catalyzed reactions of HDO. The obtained results let us conclude that the balancing of metal and acid sites plays an important role in the development of the efficient catalyst for the HDO of fatty acid esters over supported phosphide catalysts.

An Atomic-Scale View of Palladium Alloys and their Ability to Dissociate Molecular Hydrogen
Baber, Ashleigh E.; Tierney, Heather L.; Lawton, Timothy J.; Sykes, E. Charles H.

Pd and its alloys play a central role in industrial applications such as H reactions, sepns., storage devices, and as fuel cell components. Alloy compns. are complex and often heterogeneous at the at.-scale and the exact mechanisms by which many of these processes operate have yet to be discovered. Herein, scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) was used to study the at.-scale structure of Pd-Au and Pd-Cu bimetallics created by depositing Pd on both Au(111) and Cu(111) single crystals at a variety of surface temps. Individual, isolated Pd atoms in an inert Cu matrix are active for the dissocn. of H and subsequent spillover onto Cu sites. H spillover was facile on Pd-Cu at 420 K but no H was found under the same H2 flux on a Pd-Au sample with identical at. compn. and geometry. In the case of Au, significant H uptake was only obsd. when larger ensembles of Pd were present as nanoparticles. The authors report exptl. evidence for H's ability to reverse the tendency of Pd to segregate into the Au surface at catalytically relevant temps. and the STM images reveal a novel H-induced striped structure in which Pd atoms aggregated on top of the surface in regularly spaced rows. These results demonstrate the powerful influence an inert substrate has on the catalytic activity of Pd atoms supported in or on its surface and reveal how the at.-scale geometry of Pd-Au alloys is greatly affected by the presence of H.

Ni/Al2O3, Ni/MgAlO, and Ni/MgO catalysts were studied for the hydrogenation of pyridine to piperidine. Microcalorimetric adsorption and IR spectroscopy were used to study the adsorption of CO, H2, pyridine, and piperidine on the catalysts. It was found that the basic support (MgO) increased the heat of adsorption of CO on Ni, due to the increased surface electron d. of Ni, while weakened the strength of H-Ni, which might be a reason for the decreased activity of Ni/MgO for the hydrogenation of pyridine. In contrast, the acidic support (Al2O3) caused the electron-deficient surface metallic Ni that enhanced the adsorption of H2 and pyridine and thus favored the hydrogenation of pyridine. In addn., it was found that pyridine was more strongly adsorbed on Ni than piperidine although piperidine is a stronger base than pyridine, indicating that the electron-enriched arom. ring of pyridine might be involved in the adsorption of pyridine on Ni, which was favored on the electron-deficient surface Ni and acidic support.

COx-free hydrogen production from ammonia decomposition over sepiolite-supported nickel catalysts
Kurtoglu, Samira Fatma; Sarp, Seda; Yilmaz Akkaya, Ceren; Yagci, Baris; Motallebzadeh, Amir; Soyer-Uzun, Sezen; Uzun, Alper

Sepiolite, a clay mineral, was utilized as a support for nickel-based catalysts for COx-free hydrogen prodn. from ammonia decompn. First, the phys. and chem. properties of sepiolite were changed by calcining it at temps. varying from 500 to 1000 °C, then nickel was impregnated on these calcined supports and tested for ammonia decompn. at various temps. following redn. at 650 °C. Results indicated that even though the catalysts contained almost the same amt. of nickel, they showed different hydrogen prodn. performance. Detailed characterization of the catalysts before and after reaction illustrated that the support obtained by calcining sepiolite at 700 °C shows good basic properties with a high surface area offering a high degree of nickel dispersion. These properties lead to promising hydrogen prodn. rates which are on par, if not higher, than most of the nickel-based catalysts prepd. on supports, which are either not cheap or require tedious prepn. procedures.

Ni catalysts with high surface areas were prepd. from Mg-Al hydrotalcite-like compds. contg. Ni with different Mg-to-Al ratios for the prodn. of hydrogen via ammonia decompn. At at. ratios of Mg-to-Al from 3:1 to 6:1, Ni redn. was greater than 90%, and the amts. of Ni0 exposed were kept at more than 200 μmol g-1. With the increase in Mg-to-Al ratio, turnover frequency was increased due to an increase in the basicity of the support. Of the catalysts examd., Ni_MgAl(6:1) exhibited the highest NH3 conversion, which was attributed to its relatively high basicity and large amt. of Ni0 exposed.
